content: The "Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016" may be cited as the short title. It includes an FMAP adjustment for affected jurisdictions equivalent to compact migrant expenditures. The "Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016" increases the FMAP for affected jurisdictions based on estimated percentage points. The chief executive official must submit compact migrant expenditure estimates to the Secretary of the Interior. The chief executive official of the affected jurisdiction submits an estimation of compact migrant expenditures to the Secretary of the Interior before each calendar quarter. The Secretary of the Interior reviews and adjusts the estimation, then submits a final estimated amount to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of HHS estimates the increase in FMAP percentage points needed for each affected jurisdiction to result in a total Federal payment increase equivalent to the final estimated compact migrant expenditures for a quarter. The Secretary of HHS estimates the increase in FMAP percentage points needed for each affected jurisdiction to result in a total Federal payment increase equivalent to the final estimated compact migrant expenditures for a quarter, without exceeding limitations under subsections (f) and (g) of section 1108 of the Social Security Act. Notification must be given 30 days before the beginning of the calendar quarter involved. The Secretary of HHS estimates the FMAP increase for affected jurisdictions to match migrant expenditures without exceeding limitations. Notification is given 30 days before the quarter. The chief executive official of an affected jurisdiction must submit a report on migrant expenditures to the Secretary of the Interior for review and adjustments before final submission. The chief executive official of an affected jurisdiction must submit a report on migrant expenditures to the Secretary of the Interior for review and adjustments before final submission. The Secretary of Health and Human Services shall review and adjust the accounting submitted for accuracy and submit a final report on compact migrant expenditures to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The calendar quarter resulted in increased Federal payments to the affected jurisdiction under title XIX of the Social Security Act, equivalent to the final accounting of compact migrant expenditures. Adjustments to the FMAP for future quarters will be made, subject to limitations under subsections (f) and (g) of section 1108 of the Act. The FMAP for the affected jurisdiction will be adjusted for future quarters to address any overpayment or underpayment resulting from the increase in FMAP. The FMAP increase cannot exceed 100 percent for any jurisdiction. Compact migrant expenditures are not considered medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act. SEC. 4. Preference for US citizens or nationals for housing financial assistance in Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands. United States citizens or nationals have priority over eligible aliens for financial assistance. SEC. 5. Independent assessment of the strategic importance of the relationship between the United States and the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, and Palau. The Secretary of State will seek an agreement with an eligible organization to assess the strategic importance of the relationship between the United States and the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau, as part of the Asia-Pacific re-balance and for security purposes. The assessment will evaluate the capabilities, expertise, and shortcomings of US agencies in administering the Compact of Free Association with the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau, along with recommendations for improvements. The assessment will evaluate US agencies' capabilities in administering the Compact of Free Association with the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau, including recommendations for improvements, renewal, and future administration of the Compacts, and any other relevant matters determined by the eligible organization. The eligible organization must submit a report to the Secretary of State within one year of the Act's enactment. The report should include the assessment, required matters, and any other relevant issues deemed appropriate by the Secretary. The report must be in unclassified form but may contain classified information. The eligible organization may obtain official data directly from US departments or agencies to carry out the agreement. The head of the department or agency must provide the necessary information upon request. The report required by the organization should be submitted in unclassified form, with the option of including a classified annex if needed.
